case_name: The Federation v. R. K. Mittal

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 244 of 1967 was filed by special leave.

facts.text: Appeal is from the Award dated November 22, 1966 of the Labour Court, Delhi in I.D. No. 33 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated November 22, 1966 of the Labour Court, Delhi in I.D. No. 33 of 1966. B. Pai, P. N. Tiwari, and O. C. Mathur, for the appellant.

facts.text: Labour Court directed reinstatement of Respondent R. K. Mittal with full back wages and continuity of service.

anchor.surface_text: In this Appeal the Award of the Labour Court directing reinstatement of the Respondent R. K. Mittal, an employee of , the Appellant  hereinafter referred to as the Federation  with full back wages and companymittee known as the

facts.text: In February 1965, the 20th Congress of International Chamber of Commerce was held in Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: In February, 1965, the 20th Congress of International Chamber of Commerce was held in Delhi for which purpose a companymittee known as the Indian National Committee of Indian National chamber of companymerce was brought into existence

facts.text: Services of respondent R. K. Mittal and other workmen were loaned to the Indian National Committee by the Federation.

anchor.surface_text: and the service of the respondent along with other workmen were loaned to it by the Federation .The respondent worked for about 40 days but was only paid overtime for about 7 days and companys

facts.text: Respondent worked for about 40 days but was paid overtime for only about 7 days.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent worked for about 40 days but was only paid overtime for about 7 days and companysequently he claimed overtime for the remainder of the days as acccording to him other workmen had also been paid similarly.

facts.text: Respondent claimed overtime for the remaining days, alleging other workmen were paid similarly.

anchor.surface_text: but was only paid overtime for about 7 days and companysequently he claimed overtime for the remainder of the days as acccording to him other workmen had also been paid similarly. This claim was number admitted by the Federation

facts.text: Respondent issued lawyer's notice to Federation, Indian National Committee, and International Chamber of Commerce, Paris, demanding Rs. 600.

anchor.surface_text: with the result that the Respondent caused a Lawyers numberice to be issued to the Federation, to the Indian National Committee of International Chambers of Commerce and to the International Chamber of Commerce with its Head Office at Paris, demanding payment of his dues amounting to about Rs. 600/-

facts.text: International Chamber of Commerce sent telegram to Federation inquiring about handling the matter.

anchor.surface_text: When numberreplies were received, he caused another numberice to be served threatening to file a suit whereupon the International Chamber of Commerce sent a telegram to the Federation enquiring whether it should deal with the matter or whether they would deal with it.

facts.text: Federation replied to ICC that it would deal with the matter, but claim was not settled.

anchor.surface_text: To this the Federation replied that it will deal with it, but it appears that the claim of the Respondent was number settled. The Respondent then filed a suit for the payment of the arrears.

facts.text: Federation served chargesheet on Respondent for misconduct in issuing notices to ICC.

anchor.surface_text: The Federation felt that this action of the Respondent in causing legal numberices to be served on the International Chamber of Commerce was taken with a view to bringing the Federation into disrepute, and it was capable of so bringing it in the eyes of the International Chamber of Commerce which Act being inconsistent with his duties and obligations as an employee companystituted misconduct. A chargesheet was served on the Respondent

facts.text: Domestic enquiry held, Respondent found guilty of misconduct.

anchor.surface_text: A chargesheet was served on the Respondent and a domestic enquiry was held in which he was held to be guilty of misconduct. This finding was forwarded to the Secretary

facts.text: Secretary terminated services of Respondent instead of dismissing him.

anchor.surface_text: and a domestic enquiry was held in which he was held to be guilty of misconduct. This finding was forwarded to the Secretary who instead of dismissing him took a lenient view and terminated his services.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Federation's activities (exhibitions with profits, publications, arbitration, liaison services for business community) are systematic, organised like trade/business, involve employer-employee cooperation, produce material services; profit motive or charitable objects irrelevant per precedents (Safdarjung Hospital, Gymkhana Club).

holdings.text: Issuing legal notices to Federation, Indian National Committee, and International Chamber of Commerce did not constitute misconduct.

holdings.text: Decisions under Income-tax Act on charitable objects irrelevant for determining 'industry' under Industrial Disputes Act.

anchor.surface_text: We had occasion to point out during the course of the argument of the learned Advocate for the Appellant that the cases under the Income-tax Act are of little assistance in determining whether an Organisation

holdings.reasoning_summary: IT Act focuses on dominant objects for tax exemption; ID Act examines nature of activities (systematic, business-like, material services via employer-employee cooperation), not objects.

holdings.text: In absence of standing orders, Tribunal may assess proportionality of punishment and interfere if disproportionate to amount to victimisation.

anchor.surface_text: It is not denied that there are no standing orders specifying the misconduct which would justify dismissal and what misconduct would justify other disciplinary action. In these circumstances it is open to the Tribunal

holdings.reasoning_summary: No standing orders defining misconduct/punishments; Tribunal can review if punishment disproportionate (citing M. Agnani v. Badri Dass).

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: There can in our view be no doubt that the Federation is an industry within the meaning of Sec. 2 j of the Act. Now coming to the merits of the case we find little substance in the contention of the Federation that the Respondent had issued legal notices to the International Chamber of Commerce with a view to bring discredit to the Federation-its employer. The charge of misconduct that was framed against the Respondent was that he having acted in a manner inconsistent with his duties and obligations as an employee of the Federation he caused to be addressed without any justification copies of the letters to the International Chamber of Commerce with a view to bring and or capable of bringing disrepute to the Federation in the eyes of the International Chamber of Commerce.

anchor.surface_text: There can in our view be no doubt that the Federation is an industry within the meaning of Sec. 2 j of the Act. Now coming to the merits of the case we find little substance in the contention of the Federation that the Respondent had issued legal notices to the International Chamber of Commerce with a view to bring discredit to the Federation-its employer. The charge of misconduct that was framed against the Respondent was that he having acted in a manner inconsistent with his duties and obligations as an employee of the Federation he caused to be addressed without any justification copies of the letters to the International Chamber of Commerce with a view to bring and or capable of bringing disrepute to the Federation in the eyes of the International Chamber of Commerce.
